title: Geocoding GMD
text:
What happens when household surveys meet geospatial data? The Global Monitoring Database (GMD)‚Äîthe World Bank‚Äôs harmonized repository of household surveys‚Äînow includes geocoded variables that capture the spatial context of interviewed households.
Using a global grid system (H3 hexagons), survey locations are linked to powerful spatial indicators such as population density, urbanization, nighttime lights, accessibility, and climate. Nearly 100 surveys across 44 low- and middle-income countries‚Äîrepresenting about 3 million households‚Äîhave already been mapped to more than 130,000 unique locations.
This integration opens new doors for analysis, allowing researchers and practitioners to combine household data with geospatial insights to better understand living conditions and inform policy.

Using a global grid system (H3 hexagons), survey locations are linked to powerful spatial indicators such as population density, urbanization, nighttime lights, accessibility, and climate. Nearly 100 surveys across 44 low- and middle-income countries‚Äîrepresenting about 3 million households‚Äîhave already been mapped to more than 130,000 unique locations.
This integration opens new doors for analysis, allowing researchers and practitioners to combine household data with geospatial insights to better understand living conditions and inform policy.

title: AI-Assisted Coding in Stata and R
text:
This seminar provides an overview of how we can harness the power of AI in our daily analytical work. Essential tools that can significantly improve your analysis and coding workflow will be demonstrated.
Any task involving coding in Stata or R/Python programming languages can be more efficiently performed with the help of AI (such as Anthropic Claude, ChatGPT, or GitHub Copilot). However, using AI solely through a web browser or Windows Copilot captures only a fraction of its potential.
To enhance the efficiency and scope of your work, we can integrate WB-approved software (VS Code) that can incorporate AI-Agents and run Stata or R code directly. This will enable you to leverage AI in your daily analysis, make AI aware of your context, and prompt it to write code specifically to your data and objectives.
The goal of this seminar is to introduce these tools, demonstrate their potential and limitations, and provide a starting point for you to explore AI assistance independently.

title: AI-Assisted Coding in Stata and R

To enhance the efficiency and scope of your work, we can integrate WB-approved software (VS Code) that can incorporate AI-Agents and run Stata or R code directly. This will enable you to leverage AI in your daily analysis, make AI aware of your context, and prompt it to write code specifically to your data and objectives.
The goal of this seminar is to introduce these tools, demonstrate their potential and limitations, and provide a starting point for you to explore AI assistance independently.

title: AI-Assisted Coding in Stata and R
text:
Speaker
Eduard Bukin (ebukin@worldbank.org)
Opening Remarks: Gabriela Inchauste
Series Lead: Maria Eugenia Genoni (mgenoni@worldbank.org)
Moderator: Henry Stemmler (hstemmler@worldbank.org)

title: AI-Assisted Coding in Stata and R
text:
What You Will Learn
During this first session, we will:

Demonstrate how to use AI assistance in daily coding
Briefly introduce key AI-relevant concepts:

AI-Chat versus AI-Agent
Context awareness and model communication protocol (MCP)
Integrated Development Environments (IDEs): VS Code

Explain the software setup needed to leverage AI agents in analysis:

Positron/VS Code
GitHub and https://github.com/worldbank
GitHub Copilot and access to Claude LLM for coding models

Show step-by-step practical cases of AI application to produce high-quality analysis based on a general task of ‚Äúreproducibility package preparation‚Äù:

How and where to start
Effective prompt generation
Performing analysis
Quality control, validation and preventing hallucinations

Discuss further potential uses of AI-Agents in our everyday work

title: GeoPov
text:
üß† Context Awareness


Positron accesses metadata about the project. Thus AI ‚Äòknows‚Äô:

üìÅ Files str.: Code, docs
üìä Data: Var. names, types
‚èÆÔ∏è History: Edits, commands
üì¶ Environment: Packages
üéØ Intent: Current task
‚úÖ Results: Output, errors


Why does it matter?

üéØ Project-specific suggestions
üîó Understands dependencies
üõ°Ô∏è Reduces hallucinations



Read more: Positron: AI Context | GH Copilot | Claude

title: GeoPov
text:
üîå Model Context Protocol (MCP)
‚ÄúMCP is a universal adapter for AI‚Äù‚ÄîAnthropic‚Äôs invention
MCP are essential to connect everything: Stata-MCP or R MCP for Stata/R -> Positron -> Copilot -> LLMs,


Read more: modelcontextprotocol.io

title: GeoPov
text:
ü§ñ GitHub Copilot | Anthropic Claude


GitHub Copilot

‚úÖ WB-approved
üåê Accessed through github.com/worldbank
ü§ù Uses OpenAI GPT, Anthropic Claude
üîå Integrates with Positron and other IDEs


Choose your LLM:

üß† Claude Sonnet/Haiku/Opus
üí° OpenAI GPT-4/o1‚Ä¶








Sources: Anthropic Claude Sonnet 4.5

title: GeoPov
text:
‚úçÔ∏è Efficient Prompting


üéØ Be specific about the task: ‚ÄúWrite a Stata do-file to ‚Ä¶‚Äù / ‚ÄúRefactor this R function to ‚Ä¶‚Äù
üß© Provide context: goal, dataset description, key variables, constraints (WB rules, packages, runtime)
üìå Define the expected output: table/figure format, file to modify, function signature, acceptance criteria
üîÅ Ask AI to summarize + clarify first: ‚ÄúRestate the task in your own words and ask any clarifying questions before implementing.‚Äù
üîç Ask for assumptions + checks: ‚ÄúList assumptions; add validation/tests; include edge cases‚Äù
ü™ú Iterate in small steps: request a minimal working change, then refine (don‚Äôt ‚Äúrewrite everything‚Äù)
üß† Force transparency: ‚ÄúExplain why this approach; give 1‚Äì2 alternatives with trade-offs‚Äù
üßæ Make it reproducible: ‚ÄúUse set seed; pin versions; avoid randomness; write comments; ask LLM to write comments‚Äù
üõë Set boundaries: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt use external data; don‚Äôt print secrets; don‚Äôt change unrelated files‚Äù



Tip: Treat the assistant as a collaborator.

title: GeoPov
text:
‚ö†Ô∏è Limitations and Remedies

‚ö†Ô∏é Wrong-but-plausible outputs / hallucinations: code runs but logic is wrong
‚úì Verify and validate: ask the model to explain and justify the solution
‚ö†Ô∏é Context limits: not all files/data are in context; too large projects.
‚úì Be explicit: state assumptions, expected inputs/outputs, and references
‚ö†Ô∏é Outdated knowledge: suggested APIs/packages/options may have changed
‚úì Teach the model: provide references/links; ask it to learn
‚ö†Ô∏é Over-reliance: erodes fundamentals; mistakes slip through unchallenged
‚úì Keep learning: ask for step-by-step reasoning; request alternatives and trade-offs
‚ö†Ô∏é Confidentiality / security / privacy
‚úì Constrain context: exclude sensitive data; use .copilot-ignore
‚ö†Ô∏é Reproducibility: answers can vary across sessions/models/settings
‚úì Make it reproducible: save prompts, use Git; create AI agents


Read more: GitHub Copilot Trust Center

title: Maria Davalos
text: Mar√≠a Eugenia D√°valos is a Senior Economist driving analysis and evidence-based policy design to expand economic opportunity and reduce poverty. She has worked across Latin America and the Caribbean and Europe and Central Asia, and brings together analytics and operations on economic mobility, distributional impact of policies and shocks, labor markets, gender, migration, and inequality. In the past few years, Mar√≠a has increasingly focused her work on how place shapes life chances and how spatially targeted solutions can promote more inclusive growth. Her recent policy-oriented research has focused on a geographic lens to inequality of opportunity and intergenerational mobility, and ongoing work on the geography of labor markets and job quality. Beyond her analytical experience, her operational work has leveraged the Bank‚Äôs financing instruments to turn diagnostics into policy reform.

title: Maria Davalos

In the past few years, Mar√≠a has increasingly focused her work on how place shapes life chances and how spatially targeted solutions can promote more inclusive growth. Her recent policy-oriented research has focused on a geographic lens to inequality of opportunity and intergenerational mobility, and ongoing work on the geography of labor markets and job quality. Beyond her analytical experience, her operational work has leveraged the Bank‚Äôs financing instruments to turn diagnostics into policy reform.

title: Eduard Bukin
text:
Eduard Bukin is an experienced economist, data scientist, and statistician spending the last decade at the World Bank, UN, and academia. His career has focused on econometrics, economic research, microeconomics, and statistics, with a strong emphasis on empowering non-specialists to extract insights from complex datasets and effectively communicate analyses through interactive web tools, and artificial intelligence.
Key technical expertise lies in use of the modern data science technologies and programming languages such as R, Python, STATA, and GIS tools. He holds a Master‚Äôs degree in Rural Development from Ghent University and pursues a Ph.D.¬†in Agricultural Economics from Justus Liebig University Giessen.
His research focuses on land and agricultural economics in transitional countries, such as Ukraine and Kazakhstan as well as on economic modelling of trade and climate policies impacts on welfare in developing countries. His work has contributed to several peer-reviewed publications published in the Land Use Policy Journal, Environmental Research Letters, Environmental and Resource Economics and other academic outlets as well as World Bank reports, Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) publications, and internal documents.

title: Projects
text: Our work is organized around three main pillars that guide our approach to integrating geospatial data with poverty analysis.

title: Projects
text:
Our Three Pillars

Spatial Analysis
Applying a geographic lens to pressing policy questions on poverty and inequality.


Knowledge and Data Center
Building a curated repository of geospatial data sources and methods for poverty analysis.


Capacity Building
Demystifying geospatial data for microeconomists through hands-on training and peer-learning.

title: Spatial Analysis
text: We apply a geographic lens to pressing policy questions on poverty and inequality. Whether it‚Äôs identifying where jobs are (and aren‚Äôt) for the poor, mapping urban deprivation, or analyzing rural income dynamics, we use spatially disaggregated data to generate actionable insights.

title: Nga Thi Viet Nguyen
text:
A Senior Economist who is passionate about how policies shape people‚Äôs lives ‚Äî and how where they live changes the story. She‚Äôs worked across Sub-Saharan Africa, Central Asia, and the EU, combining solid economic analysis with a growing love for using spatial data to uncover new insights into welfare outcomes.
Her research has appeared in journals like the Journal of Economic Inequality, World Bank Economic Review, and Journal of Development Studies. These days, she‚Äôs especially excited about turning geospatial insights into smarter, more grounded policies that deliver real impact.

title: Henry Stemmler
text:
An Economist by training, Henry Stemmler works on poverty analysis and geospatial analytics at the World Bank. His current work explores how spatial factors shape labor market outcomes and welfare in developing countries, with a particular interest in urban job accessibility and the geographic dimensions of poverty.
He has co-authored World Bank flagship reports including the Poverty, Prosperity and Planet Report, and his work has appeared in journals such as the Economic Journal, Journal of Development Economics, World Development, and Food Policy. He holds a PhD in Economics from the University of G√∂ttingen and previously worked as a postdoctoral researcher at ETH Z√ºrich and as an Economist at the International Labor Organization.

title: Henry Stemmler
text:
An Economist by training, Henry Stemmler works on poverty analysis and geospatial analytics at the World Bank. His current work explores how spatial factors shape labor market outcomes and welfare in developing countries, with a particular interest in urban job accessibility and the geographic dimensions of poverty.
He has co-authored World Bank flagship reports including the Poverty, Prosperity and Planet Report, and his work has appeared in journals such as the Economic Journal, Journal of Development Economics, World Development, and Food Policy. He holds a PhD in Economics from the University of G√∂ttingen and previously worked as a postdoctoral researcher at ETH Z√ºrich and as an Economist at the International Labor Organization.

title: Welcome to GeoPov
text: üåç We are a group of development economists and geospatial enthusiasts working at the intersection of poverty, place, and policy. At GeoPov, we believe that where people live matters just as much as how they live ‚Äî and we‚Äôre here to make sure that spatial realities are part of the poverty dialogue.

title: Welcome to GeoPov
text:
üéØ Our Goal
To develop a global agenda that:

Empowers economists by integrating geospatial data and spatial analysis into country-level diagnostics and policy engagement.
Contributes to global knowledge that helps design local solutions grounded in data and spatial context.

title: Welcome to GeoPov
text:
üß≠ What We Do
Our work is organized around three main pillars:

Pillar 1: Spatial Analysis
We apply a geographic lens to pressing policy questions on poverty and inequality. Whether it‚Äôs identifying where jobs are (and aren‚Äôt) for the poor, mapping urban deprivation, or analyzing rural income dynamics, we use spatially disaggregated data to generate actionable insights. This includes household surveys, censuses, administrative records, private sector data, and satellite-based remote sensing ‚Äî covering everything from climate and land use to infrastructure and conflict. We also develop and share open, reproducible code and tools that can be adapted across countries and topics.
Learn more about our Spatial Analysis work ‚Üí


Pillar 2: Knowledge and Data Center
We bring clarity to the what, why, and how of using geospatial data in poverty analysis. This pillar focuses on:

Building a curated repository of geospatial data sources and methods, with clear guidance on how they can (and can‚Äôt) be used in applied work.
Showcasing examples of microeconomic analyses that successfully integrate geospatial data to answer real-world policy questions.

Explore our Knowledge and Data Center ‚Üí


Pillar 3: Capacity Building
We help demystify geospatial data for microeconomists. Through hands-on trainings and peer-learning events, we build core skills for microeconomists to use geospatial methods with confidence. Whether you‚Äôre just getting started or looking to refine your toolkit, we‚Äôre here to support you through our growing Community of Practice.
Explore our seminars and training events ‚Üí

The Challenge

Analysis workflows are becoming more complex
Code quality and reproducibility are critical
Time constraints limit thorough documentation
Knowledge sharing across teams is difficult

title: AI Agent-Assisted Workflow
text:
The AI Revolution
Traditional tools capture only a fraction of AI potential:


Limited Approach

Web browser ChatGPT
Windows Copilot
Isolated AI interactions


Integrated Approach

Context-aware AI agents
Integrated development environment
Project-specific assistance

title: AI Agent-Assisted Workflow

AI-Chat

Conversational interface
General purpose assistance
Limited context awareness

AI-Agent

Autonomous task execution
Full project context
Integrated with development tools

title: AI Agent-Assisted Workflow

Enables AI to understand your project structure
Accesses your data and code context
Provides targeted, relevant assistance

title: AI Agent-Assisted Workflow
text:
The AI-Assisted Toolkit

Positron/VS Code - Your development environment
GitHub & GitHub Copilot - Code suggestions and completions
Claude LLM - Advanced reasoning and analysis
Stata/R Integration - Direct language support

title: AI Agent-Assisted Workflow

title: AI Agent-Assisted Workflow
text:
Use Case: Reproducibility Package
The Task
Create a complete, documented analysis package:

Clean, well-structured code
Comprehensive documentation
Quality checks and validation
Ready for publication

title: AI Agent-Assisted Workflow

Step 2: Effective Prompting
Bad Prompt ‚ùå

‚ÄúWrite code to analyze data‚Äù

Good Prompt ‚úÖ

‚ÄúCreate an R script that loads household survey data from ‚Äòdata/survey.csv‚Äô, calculates poverty rates by region, and produces a summary table with confidence intervals‚Äù

title: AI Agent-Assisted Workflow
text:
Step 3: Code Generation
With AI Assistance

Autocomplete: Real-time code suggestions
Documentation: Automatic comment generation
Best Practices: Style and structure recommendations

title: AI Agent-Assisted Workflow
text:
Step 4: Quality Control
Preventing Hallucinations

Always review AI-generated code
Test with your actual data
Verify statistical methods
Cross-check results
Use version control

title: AI Agent-Assisted Workflow
text:
Real-World Benefits


Time Savings

30-50% faster coding
Automated documentation
Quick debugging


Quality Improvements

Consistent coding style
Comprehensive error handling
Better documentation

title: AI Agent-Assisted Workflow
text:
Limitations & Considerations

AI can make mistakes (hallucinations)
Requires domain knowledge to verify
Data privacy considerations
Not a replacement for expertise

title: AI Agent-Assisted Workflow
text:
Best Practices

Start Small - Begin with simple tasks
Iterate - Refine prompts and outputs
Validate - Always check results
Learn - Understand the code generated
Share - Contribute to team knowledge

title: Positron + Github Copilot: Setup Instructions
text:
Setup software environment for AI agent-assisted analysis in Stata and R
Enable GitHub Copilot or Claude AI integration
Be able to reproduce AI-assisted coding workflow demonstrated in the seminar

title: Positron + Github Copilot: Setup Instructions
text:
Software setup

Step 1. Prerequisite Software: Stata, R, Python
Go to the World Bank Software Center App and install the following software (if not already installed) :









Software
Notes





Stata 19 or higher (latest available)




R 4.5.2 (latest)




Python 3.13+ (latest)




Quarto 1.3.343 (latest)
May require software installation request



Git 2.52+ (latest)




GitHub Desktop Latest
Optional





Step 2. Install Required Python Package

Open Command Prompt (cmd) or PowerShell:

Press Win + R, type cmd or powershell, and hit Enter.

Type pip install uv and press Enter to install the uv package.

uv is a package that allows environments management in python, see https://pypi.org/project/uv/

Check if UV is installed correctly by typing uv --version in the Command Prompt or PowerShell. You should see the version number displayed, something like this:
uv 0.9.18 (0cee76417 2025-12-16)



Step 3. Install Positron (IDE) 1

Download Positron from https://positron.posit.co/download.html







Warning



Important: Use ‚ÄúWindows 10, 11 x64 (system level install)‚Äù, not the ‚Äúuser level install‚Äù



Make a ‚ÄúSoftware Installation Request‚Äù on eservice.

Go to eservices/
Select ‚ÄúSoftware Installation Request‚Äù
See KB0076748 for more details.

Once approved, you will have two options to install Positron:

ITS Personnel will connect to your computer remotely and install Positron using an admin password.
You will need an admin password to install Positron yourself.

Either way, follow these installation instructions:

Step 1: Copy the executable (exe) or installation folder to C:\WBG.
Step 2: Launch the command shell (cmd.exe) as an administrator.
Step 3: Navigate to C:\WBG in the command shell.
Step 4: Set the user profile, TEMP, and TMP environments, and launch the executable from the shell prompt by typing:
set userprofile=c:\wbg\temp
set temp=c:\wbg\temp\temp
set tmp=c:\wbg\temp\temp
Positron-20XX.XX.X-XXX-Setup-x64.exe
Note: Replace Positron-20XX.XX.X-XXX-Setup-x64.exe with the actual filename of the Positron installer you downloaded.




Step 4. Install Extensions in Positron
Extensions are add-ons that enhance Positron‚Äôs functionality. To install extensions, open the Extensions panel by clicking the square icon  on the left sidebar or pressing Ctrl+Shift+X. There are many extensions available for Positron. Below are the key extensions to install for AI-assisted analysis:

Stata MCP
Stata MCP Extension enables Model Communication Protocol (MCP) for Stata, providing better context awareness for AI agents and allowing you to run Stata code directly from Positron.
To install it:








Description





Open the Extensions panel in Positron



Search for ‚ÄúStata MCP‚Äù in the Extensions panel



Click ‚ÄúInstall‚Äù to add the extension to Positron



After installation, restart Positron or reload the window (Ctrl+Shift+P > Developer: Reload Window > Enter)



Once installed, configure the Stata MCP extension by setting up the path to the Stata executable and Stata edition.

Open stata-vscode.stataPath or press Ctrl+, > search ‚ÄúStata Path‚Äù (or stata-vscode.stataPath), and set it to your Stata executable folder: C:\Program Files\StataNow19\ (for most WB laptops and VDIs). 
Open stata-vscode.stataEdition
or press Ctrl+, > search ‚ÄúStata Edition‚Äù (or stata-vscode.stataEdition), and
set it to ‚Äúmp‚Äù for Stata MP version.



Verify Stata MCP is working:

Create and save a new Stata .do file
Type a simple command like: stata     sysuse auto     summarize price     display "Stata is working!"
Press Ctrl+Shift+D in the .do file or Ctrl+Shift+P > type Stata: Run Current File > Enter to run the do file or click on the button 
Results from Stata should appear in the Output panel: Press Ctrl+Shift+P > Output: Show Output Channels... > Enter > Stata. 



Other relevant extensions
Quarto Extension enables Quarto document editing and rendering in Positron.

title: Positron + Github Copilot: Setup Instructions
text:
Connecting GitHub Copilot to Positron
This step enables you to use the GitHub Copilot coding agent and other LLMs, such as ChatGPT or Anthropic Claude, with Positron.
See Positron Assistant: Getting Started for the full overview of what it does.

Step 1. Connect GitHub to Positron
This requires a GitHub account linked to the World Bank organization. See GitHub Setup [@github-setup] instructions below if you don‚Äôt have an account or haven‚Äôt linked it to the WB organization. To connect GitHub to Positron:








Note





Open Account menu



Click Sign in to your GitHub account



Authorize GitHub in your browser



Confirm the authorization request



Complete the authentication process



Grant necessary permissions









Step 2. Enabling Positron Assistant in Positron Settings

Open settings positron.assistant.enable and check the box to enable it. or Ctrl+, > positron.assistant.enable > Check the box 
Restart Positron to apply the changes
or reload the window (Ctrl+Shift+P > Developer: Reload Window > Enter) 

See Enable Positron Assistant for more details.


Step 3. Configure LLM Provider
By default, when logged into GitHub, Positron Assistant uses GitHub Copilot as the LLM provider. GitHub Copilot provides code completion, answers questions in chat, and operates in agent mode (able to run code directly).






Warning



Note: Within GitHub Copilot, you can also configure other LLM providers, such as Anthropic Claude, OpenAI GPT, etc.


If you want to use Anthropic Claude or other LLMs as the provider, follow instructions in Configure language model providers.






Warning



Note: Code completion will still be provided by the GitHub Copilot extension or will not work with Anthropic Claude.




Step 4. Using Positron Assistant

Ctrl+Shift+P > Help: Ask Positron Assistant > Enter to open it.
In the input box that appears, type your question. For example: Write a Stata do file that loads the auto dataset and summarizes the price variable.     Open it.     Explain how to run it.

To learn more about using Positron Assistant, see Use Positron Assistant

title: Positron + Github Copilot: Setup Instructions
text:
GitHub Setup
To use GitHub Copilot in Positron, you need to have a GitHub account linked to the World Bank organization and obtain Copilot access.

Step 1: Create a GitHub Account
If you don‚Äôt have a GitHub account yet, create one at https://github.com/signup






Warning



Note: Use your personal email address, not your World Bank email.




Step 2: Join the World Bank GitHub Organization

Submit a ‚ÄúJoin GitHub Organization Account Request‚Äù on eServices to join github.com/worldbank
Once your request is approved, you will receive an email invitation to join the World Bank GitHub organization

Email will be sent to the email address associated with your GitHub account

Accept the invitation by clicking the link in the email

You need to confirm your membership in the World Bank organization on GitHub by following steps indicated in the email.
If you don‚Äôt confirm within a few days, the invitation will expire, and you will need to request again through eService.




Step 3: Request GitHub Copilot Access

After joining the World Bank organization, request GitHub Copilot access through your team lead or organization administrator
Your request will be reviewed and approved by the GitHub organization administrators

Note: Bryan Cahill leads the github.com/worldbank organization and can help with Copilot access requests

Once approved, you‚Äôll be able to use GitHub Copilot in Positron



Step 4: Verify GitHub Copilot Access

Open Positron and sign in to your GitHub account (see ‚ÄúConnecting GitHub Copilot to Positron‚Äù section above)
Check that the GitHub Copilot extension is active in the Extensions panel
Try typing a comment in a code file to verify that Copilot suggestions appear

title: Positron + Github Copilot: Setup Instructions

title: Positron + Github Copilot: Setup Instructions
text:
Footnotes


Alternatively, you can use Visual Studio Code (VS Code) as your IDE. We encourage using Positron for its better context awareness when developing R/Stata and analysis scripts. VS Code can be installed from the Software Center. Note that some steps below may differ when using VS Code instead of Positron. VS Code does not have many built-in R language features that Positron has out-of-the-box and lacks key bindings relevant to data science tasks.‚Ü©Ô∏é

title: GeoPov BBL Series
text:
This webinar series creates a platform for dialogue on how geospatial data can strengthen analysis and policy discussions aimed at reducing poverty and vulnerability. It has two main objectives:

Showcasing impactful applications ‚Äì highlighting country experiences and operational work where geospatial tools have improved poverty analysis, targeting, and decision-making. These cases illustrate models with potential for scaling up and replication in other contexts.
Sharing technical knowledge ‚Äì presenting innovative geospatial data sources, tools, and methodologies relevant for economists and practitioners working at the country level, with a focus on practical skills.

Through these conversations, the series seeks to bridge the gap between cutting-edge technical innovations and their use in shaping policies that can make a measurable difference for the poorest and most vulnerable populations.
Suggestions for future topics and speakers are warmly welcome ‚Äì please reach out to Henry Stemmler (hstemmler@worldbank.org).
